title: Science / Science & Exploration
author: Cathleen O'Grady
description: Serving the Technologist for more than a decade. IT news, reviews, and analysis.
cleaned_text: Science / Science & Exploration - [Abused women twice as likely to experience depression, new study shows](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/abused-women-twice-as-likely-to-experience-depression/) Confounding factors like poverty can't account for the total increase in risk. - [Arizona court protects climate scientists' e-mails from think tank](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/arizona-court-protects-climate-scientists-e-mails-from-think-tank/) Scientific discussions, student information both protected from disclosure. - [Russia: We're building a new space station with NASA. NASA: huh?](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/russia-were-building-a-new-space-station-with-nasa-nasa-huh/) Russia wants to build a replacement for the ISS, but NASA is looking to Mars. - [2,636 Icelandic genomes pinpoint risk for Alzheimer's, other diseases](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/icelandic-genomes-pinpoint-risk-for-alzheimers-other-diseases/) "Molecular national selfie" combines genetics with historical and medical data. - [New, whole-virus vaccine for Ebola effective in primates](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/new-whole-virus-vaccine-for-ebola-effective-in-primates/) Novel whole virus vaccine offers promising protection against Ebola infection - [Suppressing old memories key to learning new ones](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/suppressing-old-memories-key-to-learning-new-ones/) The more you forget, the better you can remember. - [Critical ocean circulation in Atlantic appears to have slowed](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/critical-ocean-circulation-in-atlantic-appears-to-have-slowed/) It might be more sensitive to temperature changes than models project. - [Childhood abuse victims don't always grow up to be abusers](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/childhood-abuse-victims-dont-always-grow-up-to-be-abusers/) Families with abuse histories might be more scrutinized by social services. - [Colliding galaxy clusters offer strongest case yet for dark matter](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/colliding-galaxy-clusters-offer-stongest-case-yet-for-dark-matter/) Observations cannot be explained without the existence of dark matter. - [Graphene allows strange form of ice to occur at room temperature](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/graphene-allows-strange-form-of-ice-to-occur-at-room-temperature/) And it may explain some of the unusual behaviors of water. - [Massive Antarctic glacier more vulnerable than previously thought](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/massive-antarctic-glacier-more-vulnerable-than-previously-thought/) Warmer water may reach an ice shelf that holds back 3 meters of sea level rise. - [NASA announces details of its asteroid redirection mission](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/nasa-announces-details-of-its-asteroid-redirection-mission/) Will remove a boulder from an asteroid, test planetary defense tech. Paul Sutter walks us through the future of climate change—and things aren't great This episode of Edge of Knowledge focuses on our rapidly transforming world. - [Virtual noses keep real-world VR sickness at bay](https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/03/virtual-noses-keep-real-world-vr-sickness-at-bay/) Simulation sickness solution may have been sitting right in front of our faces. - [Kids who are adopted get a boost in IQ](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/kids-who-are-adopted-get-a-boost-in-iq/) Study finds new evidence that intelligence is "environmentally malleable." - [BP pulls out of climate denial group even as execs support Sen. Inhofe](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/bp-pulls-out-of-climate-denial-group-even-as-execs-support-sen-inhofe/) ALEC continues to lose corporate backers over climate issues. - [Organic LEDs, carbon nanotubes may light up future fabrics](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/organic-leds-carbon-nanotubes-may-light-up-future-fabrics/) Researchers find that light-emitting devices can be woven into fabrics. - [FEMA to require state grant recipients plan for climate change](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/fema-to-require-state-grant-recipients-plan-for-climate-change/) Three years after a climate change policy statement, the agency finally acts. - [Big solar plants produced 5% of California's electricity last year](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/big-solar-plants-produced-5-of-californias-electricity-last-year/) But boom in capacity barely offsets the loss of hydroelectric power. - [Neolithic culture may have kept most men from mating](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/neolithic-culture-may-have-kept-most-men-from-mating/) Y chromosome diversity suggests male reproductive bottleneck 8,000 years ago. - [Elon Musk puts SpaceX photos into the public domain](https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2015/03/elon-musk-puts-spacex-photos-into-the-public-domain/) NASA images have been free by default, but private space flight is another story. - [New DNA construct can set off a "mutagenic chain reaction"](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/new-dna-construct-can-set-off-a-mutagenic-chain-reaction/) Can sweep through an entire population, changing a gene. - [Carefully timed questions can bias moral decisions](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/carefully-timed-questions-can-bias-moral-decisions/) But most moral decisions are still influenced by prior commitments - [Doing astronomy with neutrinos](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/doing-astronomy-with-neutrinos/) The nearly massless particles could tell us a lot if we could listen. - [Gallery: Trippy biomedical images from the Wellcome Trust](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/gallery-trippy-biomedical-images-from-the-wellcome-trust/) Close-ups of a cat's tongue, neurons in a mouse brain, and more. - [Warm Arctic winter starts sea ice off at a record low](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/warm-arctic-winter-starts-sea-ice-off-at-a-record-low/) Temperatures up by 10°C in some areas of the Arctic suppressed ice growth. - [US Interior Department announces new rules governing fracking](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/us-interior-department-announces-new-rules-governing-fracking/) Well integrity checks, disclosure of fracking fluid components now mandatory. - [MRIs show our brains shutting down when we see security prompts](https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/03/mris-show-our-brains-shutting-down-when-we-see-security-prompts/) This is your brain after repeated security warnings. Any questions? - [Nickel oxide films enhance solar-driven splitting of water](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/nickel-oxide-films-enhance-solar-driven-splitting-of-water/) Keep photovoltaic electrodes active for much longer. - [DNA map of UK migration history shows Vikings drew the line at pillaging](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/dna-map-of-uk-migration-history-shows-vikings-drew-the-line-at-pillaging/) Analysis shows less Viking DNA than expected, and no single group of Celts. - [Liquid droplets that chase each other across a surface](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/liquid-droplets-that-chase-each-other-across-a-surface/) Evaporation and humidity create dynamic dances among drops of a solution. - [New nonstop 3D printing process takes only minutes instead of hours](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/new-nonstop-3d-printing-process-takes-only-minutes-instead-of-hours/) With a bit of UV and oxygen, solid objects emerge from a shallow liquid bath. - [Developed areas in Calif. could support enough solar to power the state](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/developed-areas-in-calif-could-support-enough-solar-to-power-the-state/) And leave enough left over to power desalination plants. - [Politicians can sway voters through town hall events](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/politicians-can-sway-voters-through-town-hall-events/) US Congresspersons participated in online chats as part of an experiment. - [NASA's MAVEN spots auroras, dust at high altitudes above Mars](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/nasas-maven-spots-auroras-dust-at-high-altitudes-above-mars/) The auroras are driven by the sun, but we don't know where the dust came from. - [What would microbes on another planet look like from Earth?](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/what-would-microbes-on-another-planet-look-like-from-earth/) For most of history, life on Earth was microbial. It may be so on exoplanets. - [A common over-the-counter cough suppressant can boost insulin](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/03/a-common-over-the-counter-cough-suppressant-can-boost-insulin/) Type 2 diabetics could benefit from a drug that's already on the market.
